body.p: We say that a point estimator is unbiased if which of the following is true?

input.choice: Its sampling distribution is centered exactly at the parameter it estimates.
The standard deviation of its sampling distribution decreases as the sample size increases.
Its value is always equal to the parameter it estimates.

response.feedback: Correct. This is the definition of an unbiased estimator.
Incorrect. The standard deviation of the sampling distribution will decrease as the sample size increases regardless of the bias of the point estimator.
Incorrect. By the Central Limit Theorem, we know that sampling distributions are mostly normal regardless of the bias of the point estimator.

Incorrect. The only requirement for a point estimator to be unbiased is that the expected value of the point estimator is the same as the associated population parameter value, not that it is always equal to the parameter value.

body.p: When the sampling distribution of a statistic centers exactly around the parameter it estimates we can say that the statistic is which of the following?

response.feedback: Correct. We say that a statistic is unbiased if its distribution centers exactly around the parameter it estimates.
Incorrect. Although some sampling distributions are normally distributed, where a distribution centers does not determine its shape.
Incorrect. The statistic will vary from sample to sample and thus will rarely “exactly” equal the parameter.
Incorrect. Statistically significant means that the difference between the statistic and the assumed population value is so large it cannot be due to chance.
